author: Nick C.

description:
Please can I just eat here every day. Prices are good, staff is polite, place is clean, blah blah blah. No real place to eat here but when I come here for lunch on work days we just pop in and pop out. Never much of a line (so far....but I think it's gaining popularity and I'm sure I'm not helping that) and just SO MUCH better than Sushirrito.

Ingredients are pretty fresh, LOVE the sauces inside, and overall tastes like a big sushi roll wrapped up. I love sushi and Sushirrito was just...not sushi-y enough for me, flavors weren't that good. This place gives you a pack of soy sauce with which to enjoy your taka roll and that's not nearly enough but still, so yummy.

I have gotten the Sushi Taka roll and the spicy version of that roll and prefer the spicy one but both are really good. Less greasy than Sushirrito and more options. It's like subway for sushi burritos! You can pick a roll or ask for something else. They also have sushi bolls, actual sushi rolls, and rice balls that my coworkers seem to think decently of. Prices are good. Yum! I want to go back!

One sushi burrito is decently sized but usually I'm not full by the end of it. My coworkers usually go for a rice ball or miso soup alongside the burrito (although rice balls are um...mostly rice so...don't expect an outstanding meat-to-rice ratio) but I've been fine with just the one burrito.
author: Katie V.

description:
Why people keep referring to these things as burritos is beyond me. It's just a slightly fatter than normal sushi roll that hasn't been cut into pieces yet. Once the novelty wears off, it tastes just like those other mediocre sushi joints.

My friend was dying to try Sushiritto, but settled on this place. She couldn't warrant paying over $10 for a sushi roll (neither could I). We arrived before noon and the place was empty. The guy behind the register was really friendly and helpful. (I think his name was Brian because that's what the receipt said). He explained we could build our own sushi using the DIY menu or choose one of their preset rolls. I went with DIY and had the salmon, spicy fish roe, wasabi kanikama, cucumber and miso dressing. Friend had the king roll, but substituted the kimchi for fish roe. 

Overall, it was just okay. There's nothing exceptional about the taste that makes me want to come back. So how is this different than your average sushi restaurant? Taste-wise, there's no difference. However, if you like your sushi to be served as one giant roll rather than pieces, then come here. Also, for $8.50, the portion is a bit small. I wasn't very full after my first roll and definitely could have had a second roll.
author: Lorraine G.

description:
The menu is a little confusing at times, since they say:
1.  guac instead of avocado
2.  fish cake instead of imitation crab meat

but it is amazing.  Mix it up by trying some of the ready to go meals.  I woud suggest the inari sampler.  It has a bit of sweet, a bit of savory and entirely delicious.  

Food is also ready super fast
author: Jessica P.

description: I've worked with Sushi Taka for catering and have always gotten fantastic service. Nick is extremely kind and always a pleasure to work with. He's very willing to customize dishes to fit all dietary restrictions and reliable with deliveries. Their sushi bowls are perfectly portioned for catering, healthy but still filling, and high quality. An all around favorite of mine for top notch service and delicious food!
author: Molly M.

description: Tasty sushi wrap rolls (channeling Sushiritto at a reduced price) and sushi bowls. They take FiveStars and use Yelp Check-in to get a free miso soup.
author: Jing D.

description:
This is a tough one.  

This is obviously a sole-proprietor shop, and the owner was extremely friendly and eager to assist (both of which are critical).  However his cook prepared the food with all the interest of your average bus driver. I couldn't help but notice when he used the same hands he was handling raw fish with are the same hands opening cabinets, operating the microwave, and everything else - no wiping, just straight from fish to appliances and back again.  This normally would be a deal-breaker for me, but again the proprietor was so friendly I decided to let it go.

So, the roll is essentially a large sushi roll.  I asked for the Taka Roll, Tuna/Salmon/crab/tobiko.  The rice was perfect, delicious!  The crab was a bit too mayonnaise-heavy, but tasty anyway!  The two, small french-fry pieces of fish (one of tuna and one of salmon) were nice flavor bonuses for eating a roll of rice, but honestly if I didn't know they were there I wouldn't have noticed them.   That's a problem, and for me a big one.  40% of the roll is mayo-crab, 50% is rice, 10% fish?

Imagine you ordered a regular Tekka Maki and got a string of fish the size and shape of a drinking straw, the rest of the roll being rice.  That's what happened here.

So why three stars?  Because it was tasty.  Because it wasn't very expensive ($10 out the door.) Because the owner clearly loves his place and maybe I went on an off-day.  I strongly suspect he wouldn't short-change me the fish.  Because the tiny scrap of fish I had was fresh.

Because I'll likely be going back.
author: Matt H.

description:
-This place is better, fresher, cheaper than Sushirrito.
-Portion is perfect for lunch. Rice to fish ratio is perfect.
-Real, fresh, raw fish (sushi, tuna)
-Gets creative with new ingredients: roe, shredded japanese egg (tomago) and nice sauces (wasabi mayo, etc.)
-I ordered a miso soup on a freezing day with a Taka Roll (their most popular), total was $11.
-Nick the owner, is gracious and kind. I walked in towards the end of their "closing shift" for the day. He sent me home with a box of free sushi (california rolls, teriyaki california rolls, sushi with japenese pickles).

Nick, thank you for this great establishment. You are a nice man, and you make a really good, fast, compact lunch to go.
author: Tian L.

description:
I'll keep it short: I love sushi. I'm not a sushi snob. Sushi Taka's sushi is pretty good. I had two custom made spicy salmon rolls and they were both pretty good. Also the workers are nice and goofy, and honest and didn't try to take my money when I forgot I prepaid online. 
Only negative: they skimped a little on the fish on one of my rolls. Rice was also not the freshest but nowhere near hard or anything.
Bottom line, cheap tasty sushi closeby in Chinatown/ FiDi.
Definitely going back on my lunch break sometime.
author: Karen C.

description: I ordered the Super Bowl ($9.65) and Miso Soup ($1.00) when you buy the bowl or wrap. It was good however the portion was deceiving. I thought what I got wasn't going to last me through the end of the day and I was right... It had a lot of flavor and something different for a change. Come by and grab a bite to eat if you're around!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Seriously bro. You're just going to microwave my teriyaki chicken. Like not even be Discrete about it?

Sorry, but drizzling sauce on it wasn't enough to fool be either. The most honest but utterly disgraceful bento I've had in my life. Thank you very much, and I mean that in the most sarcastic way possible.

On top of that I was super hungry, way to just annoy me.
author: Sani S.

description:
walked 10 blocks in 80 degree heat during prime lunch hour to pay $10 for tuna smaller than the head of my pinky.

lots of rice. 

90% rice.  5% fish.

wasn't bad.  but an extreme shocker.
author: Samantha W.

description:
We had Sushi Taka on site for custom made sushi rolls Friday and they were delicious. Fish was fresh and love that they could be customized. Perhaps a little too much rice, but the rolls were good. 

Highly recommended for on site catering function.
author: Bob L.

description: Not as good as Sushiritto, but the lines are shorter and the fish is fresh. I wish they used real crab or at least had the option.
author: Adrienne G.

description: I haven't had a lot of exposure to sushi, but my daughter wanted to have it for lunch so we ended up here.  I'm glad we did!  We shared a Spicy Tuna Roll, which they cut in half for us.  It had all the components of what I consider high quality food: Fresh ingredients, and a blend of texture and flavors that played well together.  I also want to mention the helpful friendliness of someone I assume was maybe the owner or a manager.  He handed us menus while we stood in line, visited with us. When he heard my daughter was on the lookout for bubble tea, he not only suggested a quick spot to go for it, but walked us down around the block to the location, gave us tips for ordering and then pointed out a  pleasant nearby spot where we could and did enjoy our lunch.  Charming!
author: Marie K.

description:
Mirroring the app bubble, the recent craze in SF food innovation is "incremental improvement."

The sushi burrito concept is simple...save the sushi chef some time cutting, and the grab-on-the-go customer the risk of their precious sushi pieces tumbling to the ground, and you get a uniquely American concept - the uncut sushi roll.

As out-of-this-world decadent as the turbaconducken? Hardly. As mind-bending as the ending of Inception? I doubt it. But I'll have to admit it's damned convenient.

I had the Sushi Taka special; looking forward to the half salmon, half tuna recipe. The fish at sushi taka was good; but I'm a purist, and there was a heck of a lot of other random stuff in the sushi. The shredded tamago was not sweet enough, and I'm just not sure I appreciated the amount of imitation crab/mayo stuffed in. Perhaps I should have made a custom roll. Just the food: three stars.

I had to bump them up a star though, for being amazingly nice. It's actually a little refreshing after being crowed at by the delectable staff at neighboring Chinatown joints around the corner to have someone willing to prepare your food with a civilized attitude. I was a super-pain about the sauce, and they accommodated me without flinching. So service: five stars.

Worth a try regardless - it's just a $7.50 investment and may rock your world.
author: Sayaka T.

description: Favorite place for lunch... Cheaper than Sushirrito but just as great! I get the SPICY TAKA ROLL every time! It's delicious... They're really nice too. Better off calling your order in because the OrderAhead app is off. Says it's closed all the time. Food takes less than 5 minutes if there isn't a big order ahead of you.
author: Isabelle L.

description:
Quick. Fresh. Friendly. 

Not quite cheap but not expensive either.

Unagi roll was good.  Quality was as good as one can expect a sushi burrito to be

Will come back and try more filling combinations
author: Greg M.

description:
Unfortunately, I haven't tried out this place for lunch yet.  I usually come here in the mornings for my second breakfast and grab a quick spam misubi or spam loco moco.  Spam is way better than normal loco moco anyway :-p

Nick, the owner, is super friendly here and if you come here enough he'll recognize you.  One day offered me coffee because I looked cold coming into the store. 

The Inari sampler was pretty good, and also the unagi rice with egg (breakfast item also), that was recently added.  

For the price totally worth it, or you could always grab a quick breakfast, get a second item for a lunch since it is very reasonably priced.
author: Omar L.

description: I think the current 4 star rating is right on point. Very friendly staff, with the owner working the counter. They give you LOTS of fish and food, free miso and edamame. It was my first time there, and I got the spicy salad bowl. Lots of food and fresh greens; I couldn't finish it. The food was good and everything fresh, but really lacking on the "spicy" side. Overall, I think they could add more sauce as well as some ginger to really punch up the dish, but the value is really there. Decent food at a good price. Tip - ask for extra sauce if flavor is your thing.
author: Jen J.

description:
Decent rolls. Good prices. Friendly staff. But...

This place smells like old, stagnant fish. That's not something you want to be smelling in a place that serves raw fish.
author: J. S.

description:
I love burritos, and I love sushi, so naturally I love this place! 

The sushi rolls are delicious, they pretty much melt in your mouth. You can either make your own roll, or order one from their menu. Great place to stop for a quick bite. Virtually no wait, they make the sushi rolls so quickly.

Also, if you fill out a form that tells the owner your favorite roll, you get 10% off that roll every single time.
author: Alice W.

description:
Came here on the afternoon of Christmas Eve, since my boyfriend and I were craving Sushiritto and they were closed.

This place was like a customizable version of Sushiritto.  Sushi filling inside a giant, burrito-sized rice rolI.  I got a salmon roll with various veggies (you can put in as many veggies as you want) and miso sauce.  The roll itself was tasty, but there was not that much filling inside.  It was really easy to pull out the entire piece of fish, thus leaving you with half a roll of rice, but no fish.

The service was really fast.  After ordering, it took less than 5 minutes for our order to be ready.  Price is on par with Sushiritto (about ~$9 for a roll), but in terms of quantity, you don't get that much.  I wasn't hungry that morning, so I was full at the end; however I would be left hungry if I had started hungry.  This place is not bad, but I'd much rather go to Sushiritto.
author: Denise C.

description:
I wanted to save my 300th review for a place that pretty much sums up my Yelp experience. Sushi Taka has all of what I look for-- charming concept, a steal (thanks to Yelp deals), delicious food and a friendly owner. I've always considered myself an advocate for local businesses and I think Sushi Taka really reinforced why.

I strolled into Sushi Taka with a Yelp Deal in hand expecting a Sushirrito experience. I'm so glad I didn't get that experience because that would mean I would never come back. For starters, my roll was not passed on in an assembly line like they do at Chipotle and the roll is definitely much more flavorful than Sushirrito. For $5, I walked away with a unagi/spicy salmon roll with spicy tobiki, egg and terriyaki sauce, a wakame seawood salad and a bottled drink. I was greeted by the owner and was told that since it was their 3 month celebration, every customer gets a free drink. I opted for the bottled apple tea and even though the free drink only applied to canned sodas, the owner told me that it's fine. I was impressed with the spicy salmon part of my roll but was not as satisfied with the unagi. During the wait for my food, the owner really chatted me up and thanked me for taking quite a hike from my work to there. (Ok it's not that much of a hike but it was still a good 15 minute walk!) 

It's great that they open early enough for my 9AM lunch time and I'm willing to take that hike back to Sushi Taka for more rolls!
author: Tiffany U.

description: I LOVE this place. I wish they were closer to me. The cashier is always so courteous and humble. This is the service I love to rave about. It is hidden on the corner of Kearny and California and every time I come here, I always seem to forget where it is. Not only are they nice, but they are FAST. I never have to wait more than 3 minutes for my roll. I love their simplicity. No fancy schmancy rolls that are so drowned in a vinegar/citrus sauce that you can't taste the sweetness and the freshness of the fish can be found here. Their spicy rolls aren't even spicy so don't be afraid to order one. Don't forget to grab a couple of soy sauces, wasabi and pickled ginger by the door. They perfectly complement the roll.
author: Amy Z.

description: Sushi Taka is a little bit more authentically Japanese than Sushiritto, which was one of the things I liked most about it. The flavors in the spicy taka roll that I got were more simple and clean. Half of the roll had tuna and the other half had salmon, which made for a good variety. The quality of the fish was average! The roe and crab inside really made it feel like a sushi roll, and the sushi rice was acceptable. There was a little too much mayo for my taste, but I still liked the spiciness of the entire roll. Overall, it's a smaller and less complex roll than Sushiritto, but still a satisfying lunch size.
author: Ashley T.

description:
I AM IN LOVE. This is a great healthy lunch option for those who work in the Transamerica and surrounding environs. I was burned out on the usual sandwich and salad options, so I was glad to see a new place had popped up around the corner. Apparently I am 4 months behind the times, but better late than never. 

I opted for the make your own roll filled with tuna, spicy tobiko and imitation crab meat (they it call fish cake). It was positively delicious. It's like a regular sushi roll that grew up in Chernobyl or under power lines! oddly oversized. The portion made for a perfect lunch and I like to eat. It's a great $8 made to order lunch and the quality of their ingredients beats a lot of the nearby sushi joints. Fresh tuna, crisp veggies. I am for sure a repeat customer. 

I also enjoyed watching the cool gadget that turns the sushi rice into a sheet. Obviously imported from Japan - where the niftiest things are made. They also have a miso soup dispenser. You never thought you needed one until you see this thing in action! 

They also have their take on the Japadog, spam musubi, and loco moco if you aren't in the mood for their sushi burritos. 

A bonus is the proprietor is the NICEST man alive. A great man and great product. Go try now! You will be happy you did. Support small businesses! Keep the mom and pop joints alive!
author: Stacy T.

description:
You choose, they roll!  Let's get a couple things straight, it's not so much pure "sushi" as a sushi-burrito (yes I know of another shop with a similar name), second, while they advertise it's DIY (Do It Yourself), what *you* do is choose what you want in your large, burrito-sized sushi roll...*they* do the actual rolling.

I eat here around three times a week...it's close to work..it's healthy...and Nick (owner), John (sushi chef) and Julia (front counter) are really nice and eager to help.  

It's a great way to have something tasty that's also healthy, all the while supporting a small local business.  I used to visit Subway for a healthy choice, but this is much better tasting!

They also changed their hours and offer a breakfast menu and have rolls to go.  Have to admit, the spam sushi and egg & spam sushi are pretty tasty and also make for a good afternoon snack.

You choose, they roll.  Both win!
author: Jeff D.

description: I'm an East Coast kid, so was looking for some good sushi. This place served up a yummy Sushi Bowl for lunch that really hit the spot. Hadn't seen or had one of those before.
author: Dulani W.

description:
For all those wondering if this is THE replacement for Sushiritto, I'd say we have a winner. 

Better quality, ingredients, and price points. We wonder if their team "from Japan" photo on their wall is real or not. The office pool bet is coming along nicely. 

Plus, they use Square and LevelUp. Super startup-friendly restaurants always get my business.
author: Abel L.

description: Delicious sushi rolls made quick in front of you even if you go during the noon to one rush hour lunch break!
author: Mel P.

description:
Love the spot. It's quick, it's yummy, and it's a much reasonable pricing than Sushirito. Because, as fancy as you can make your ingredients, it's stil an un-cut sushi roll. This is a way economic version, without losing the taste. 

Spicy tuna / salmon mix with egg and kimchi is my favorite!!
author: Fiona S.

description:
Cute and dainty to-go sushi restaurant with friendly service and smiles all around. :)

Easy and simple concept - you're given a strip of paper with a checklist of things to go in your sushi roll. You pick "1 Main Item", "Two Other Items", the vegetables, and sauce. Your order is made in like, 5 minutes by two sushi chefs right in front of you!

Main Items (Pick one):
Salmon, tuna, spicy tuna, shrimp tempura(+$1), beef sukiyaki (+$1), kurobuta sausage, teriyaki chicken, teriyaki tofu, and half & half.

Other Items (Pick two):
Curried chicken salad, egg(shredded Japanese omelet), guacamole, kanikama(shredded fish cake), kimchi(cucumber), pico de gallo (salsa), seasonal fruit, spicy tobiko(fish roe), and takuan(Japanese radish pickles).

Vegetables(Your choice of all, or pick the ones you want):
Corn, cucumber, edamame, lettuce, onion, and tomato.

Sauce (Pick one):
Chili mayo, soy mayo, teriyaki mayo, chipotle ranch, miso dressing,  and wasabi dressing.


I got a sushi roll with spicy tuna, egg, kanikama, all vegetables, and miso dressing. The filling+rice ratio was just right, and everything tasted fresh. They cut the roll into two, and after finishing half I was full already. It's definitely sharable with a friend for a snack. Docked one star because of the price-I paid $8 plus a little change.

I'll probably be back when I'm in the area to try the other combinations! :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I came across this place on yelp. I have been working in the area for almost 5 years and I never heard of this place. What happened was that the Vietnamese coffee shop moved (the place that sells those yummy Vietnamese sandwiches) a few stores down the block and this place took over.

Actually I think I came across this through Level Up - which is awesome because you don't have to carry cash with you and plus you earn discounts when you frequent certain places. I got $1 off my first visit here today.

So I'm walking back from Union Square and I decided, this would be great to try this place out. As I'm standing across the street, I can read the Japanese characters on the awning and it spells out "su-shi" in basic Japanese characters...I'm thinking great. this is probably some Chinese owned sushi place. They probably didn't do their research to find the right character to use....BUT it turns out, the guy is from Osaka. He's a real Japanese folks, which is very rare for the SF bay area...unlike LA or Hawaii....sigh.

Anyways, he's from Osaka, the yummy food capital of Japan. He greets me at the door and describes the menu. I just pick the spicy salmon roll. I thought he was going to make it but some Mexican pops out from the back and makes my roll. 

Either way, it was great. This is why:
The sushi rice was sweet. 
The fish was great and very fresh. 
The kimchee was pretty tasty.
They take LevelUp!
it was a pretty big roll - bigger than the sample they had on display.

I don't know exactly what they put in there but I ate it all. I didn't need that much shoyu/wasabi because it was very flavorful. I'll be going back. This place is only 2 blocks from where I work too. 

Also if you've been to the Big Island or Maui,  these big rolls are very popular, but they use smoked Marlin or other cooked fish and a bunch of different spices. I love these fat rolls. 

Yum!!!

ps. I would have taken a photo but I ate my food too fast. sorry.
author: Leena C.

description:
I just ate there today, and it was great!  I had a half/half, unagi/spicy tuna with kimchi & fish balls, w/miso sauce.  It was quick, and they even have pre-made items like Spam misubi and their specialy California rolls.

The employees were courteous & attentive, and the price points for the specialty burrito style sushi rolls were about $6-12 price points, with the pre-made stuff about $5 and up.  The place is easy to find, being on the corner of Kearny & Sacramento.  Definitely will be returning here soon!

Folks in my office mentioned Sushiritto, but it was a bit further away to walk to, so we decided to check this out instead and I have no regrets doing so =)
author: Kona L.

description: Long past overdue. I got here like twice a week. This place is waaaayyy better than sushirrito. Hands down. The menu is very limited as he relies on making a few things VERY well instead of a bunch of mediocre food. The price for the quality of food you get is awesome. You can tell Nick puts a lot of effort in making each item himself.
author: JungHyun H.

description:
I made a spontaneous trip to Sushi Taka today after hearing about it for a long time. I thought it was in the financial district but it is more on the eastern border of chinatown. I did go at around 1:30 so there was no rush. I was surprised at the small location without seating but that's ok. As I was walking to Sushi Taka, I noticed the $5 for $10 deal on Yelp so I bought it instead of using LevelUp, which would've only saved me $1. 

I was greeted by Nick, who is probably the owner. Very nice, genuine guy! I was expecting more of a Sushirrito type establishment but basically it's like u-sushi fused with Sushirrito. You choose your meat/veggies and other fillings with sauce(s) and they roll it up for you in minutes. It's not cut into pieces, just in half. It's not burrito-sized if that is your expectation going in. It's more of a larger sushi roll. 

I had the unagi and shrimp tempura (half and half) with egg and fish cake. All veggies included by default. Sauce: chili mayo and miso dressing. The whole process took probably less than 5 minutes. I didn't eat it right away but the flavor remained a few hours after I settled down and had time to eat. It probably would've been a good idea to eat it right away as the tempura was soggy from the filling but the sauces definitely made up most of the flavor in every bite, so choose them wisely!
author: Dominic T.

description:
Small, unassuming exterior on the corner of Kearny and Sacramento with SUPER GOOD Japanese sushi rolls and and rice bowls!  You can "design your own roll" or choose from pre-defined rolls and bowls. 

This isn't some Japanese-esque gimmick roll place. The guy is from Japan and his place has roots there. No offense to the other places that claim to be "Japanese", but if they can't speak Japanese in the shop and if the shop's name isn't Japanese, it isn't Japanese.

Ingredients quality is HIGH and the taste and quick service is Japanese. Who cares if the FREE miso soup is dispensed from a machine....it is way better than the other place's miso because this one if from Japan. 

One reviewer said this place is a knock-off of Sushirrito, but seriously, a place named ___-rrito is surely not Japanese. Don't be a lemming by going to the places with the lines, try Sushi Taka and chat with the young Japanese owner at the counter. And, ask for their service card because you'll be back. I've been twice in two days so am already forming an addiction. Oh, and you can OrderAhead and GrubHub your order if you just want to grab and go. 

Hip is where you get to talk with the owner, not stand in a long line.
author: Flynt I.

description:
Sushirrito or Sushi Taka?  I CHOOSE Sushi Taka!! 

This is a hole in the wall on the corner of Sac and Kearny.  This is a TO-GO SPOT ONLY... I was a little sad when I realized that there was no sit-down area but curiosity already found the cat so I was committed to try this unique concept of food.

For about $8.50 you can either create a "Do It Yourself" sushi burrito with all of the additional fixings you want.  It's an easy 4 step process and it takes you through your choice of protein, additional fixings (up to 2) sauces (up to 2) and finally your veggies (unlimited and free).

I got the salmon with egg, miso sauce, edamame, cucumber and lettuce.  Delicious! They have lots of items that you can add with your sushi burrito depending on your appetite.  I didn't get any, but all the prices seemed very reasonable.  

The staff is very friendly and they definitely appear to take pride in what they do.  I mentioned that I found them on Yelp and they were excited and asked if we watched their video clip.... SO GO WATCH!  It's very entertaining and you'll actually learn just a tiny bit about where they come from and why they do what they do.  Great!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Since I work nearby and I like sushi, might as well give this place a shot. The staff was really friendly, so it's good. Too bad I dont get to try their chef's special (korean bbq beef roll). However, I customize my order with salmon, eggs & guacamole with all veggies included. I would say overall it's not bad. Just wish they put a bit more salmon and bigger piece of eggs in there. In the beginning, I was wondering if this would be filling enough (comparing it to Sushirritos' size) since I finished half already. Surprisingly, when I'm almost done, I feel full. So I guess this is the right portion for me. At the other place, the sushi is HUGE, but it's packed with rice, so it's pretty overwhelming and I never finish it.

Like other reviewers mention, I think they should have more preset rolls on their menus instead of focusing on customizing them. I want to be able to go in there and just I want a blah-blah roll and they will make it, rather than constantly referring back to the menu to look at what should I put in the roll. 

Would I go back? Probably if I'm desperate for some sushi or if I want to try their pre-made rolls that are packed already (those look yummy).
author: May K.

description:
Dear Sushirrito,

Please learn from what Sushi Taka has done right.

1. Make sure the roll is at an appropriate girth for an average mouth to handle (yes, I heard it)

2. SEASON YOUR INGREDIENTS PERFECTLY. Sushi Taka's rolls don't require much soy sauce or extra seasoning, especially if you get the spicy ones (which I highly recommend). Prepare for a trip to taste bud heaven.

3. Friendly employees with smiles on their faces. Neither you nor the lunch situation ever feels rushed or stressful

4. Amazing spam musubis and various other sushi/potsicker appetizers for a few dollars. Yum!

Sushirrito's ingredients simply don't really compliment each other well. Other than their crisp lotus chips, there was no real standout flavor or texture in any of the rolls.

Sushi Taka has got the flavor, great service, and convenience of eating down perfectly. Since discovering this place last month I've had about six rolls from Sushi Taka already. I plan to make that number 100+ by the end of 2014. :)
author: Huan L.

description:
Light but satiating sushi meal! It's wrapped up like a burrito (loving this trend, btw...) and cut in halves. I was worried there'd be too much rice but that was definitely not the case -- they don't skimp on the fish, and it tasted fresh.

I had the tuna with guacamole, egg, all the veggies, and wasabi dressing. Was delicious and I'm excited to try new combinations.

The owner was soo nice. The place itself is a hole in the wall and you can only order take-out, which is a great option for this area/ the FiDi crowd. With tax my total was just over $8, so pretty comparable to other lunch options but way cheaper than most sushi places.

They'll give you a small container of ginger and soy packets if you want. If you don't have a desk/ table to take it back to, you might want to request a plate or something... it's in the form of a burrito but seaweed doesn't wrap as tightly as a tortilla, obviously.
author: Richa A.

description: Was good. But they don't have AVOCADO. And, the size is too small for the price. But, fresh and no line. Wanted a flavor explosion but that didn't happen.
author: Andrew K.

description:
My friend found this place and we decided to give it a try. We actually wanted to try Sushirrito but we all agree that Sushirrito is too expensive for us fellow teens so we went to Sushi Taka. Sushi Taka is a neat hole-in-the wall restaurant. There's no seating space. The chalkboard menu was sort of confusing so I used the create your sushi roll menu. I got half salmon and half spicy salmon. I don't really remember what other things I got but it was very delicious. 

One other thing to mention, if you pay with a debit or credit card, they have this really cool card-sliding thing attached to the ipad to swipe the card. And then you would sign on the ipad. I thought that was pretty cool.

Staffs are all very friendly and food is very good. Will definitely go back, though it's yummy, it is not too filling, or I just eat a lot.
author: Lily L.

description: I frequently come here for the spicy rolls, which are packed with fresh and delicious ingredients. Today I decided to try the dragon bowl, and oh-my-word I would love to eat it everyday for lunch!  In the dragon bowl, a generous portion of rice is covered by tuna, salmon, seaweed, fish roe, crab, pickled ginger, pickled radish, and avocado. I love the flavor of the wasabi mayo, and it is the real deal (spicy)! The staff is so nice and friendly. Get the dragon bowl! It is delicious.
author: Yummytummy W.

description:
Yay Sushi Taka! 

This newborn of the financial district is surprisingly amazing! 
Ok i call it a sushi burrito.. and like a burrito, I love personalizing it. Sushi Taka has great choices of fish, veggies, sauces, etc.. great. 
The bf has his spam musubi at least three times a week.. again great. 
Bref, thanks sushi Taka for bringing us this delicious addition to the neighborhood :)
author: Alice G.

description: Sushi Taka is, earnestly the bomb.  A delicious and quick take-out take on sushi!
author: Mac S.

description:
It advertises itself as a DIY sushi roll, as others have pointed out, it's more accurately "Design your own sushi burrito." The "roll" you get is actually the size of a small burrito, or 2 normal sized sushi rolls.

Good price for a filling lunch (~$8). You pick one main fish/meat (I prefer the spicy salmon or shrimp tempura), 2 side fillers (I prefer egg and fish cake here), and then veggies and sauces (I prefer their wasabi dressing). They don't have a huge customer base yet, so it's really quick for a 100% custom order.

Right now they are offering a Yelp Deal ($5 for a $10 credit).
author: Chris L.

description:
You know that feeling you get right around 1:30 after you eat a burritto from either the Curry Up Now truck or one of the many burrito joints in the FiDi?  It's the feeling that causes you to check facebook every 2 minutes, browse shop on Amazon, let your calls go to voicemail.....

You don't get that feeling eating here!  It's a sushi burrito, (or sushi wrap if you will) and it's filling, delicious, healthy and oh yeah, $7-$8.  Of course, I am writing this review at 3:15pm after eating the sushi burrito from Sushi Taka, so perhaps I am feeling kind of sluggish.  Either way, it's delicious!  Don't go here, because I don't want to wait in line.

Xoxo.

P/S: They have a machine that pumps out miso soup - I love technology!
author: Josephine H.

description: Sushi rolls were okay lack of choice and plain, nothing in compare to Sushiritto. The free miso soup just doesn't help, might not go there again...
author: Eskimo M.

description: Great place for some good sushi. Not as pricy as some other places but it is still somewhat expensive. The service is great and everything I ordered came out in a timely manner. Of course it was good, otherwise I wouldn't be posting here. Really a good fine.
author: Ronald B.

description: Great and novel idea for an on-the-go healthy lunch: Make your own sushi rolls. They just opened today, and I created a salmon roll with tobiko, corn, lettuce, tomato and wasabi sauce. Any combination can be created and other options include tuna, spicy tuna, sukiyaki beef, fish cakes, etc. Their golden oolong Teas' Tea is the best bottled tea I've tried. I'll be back fo'sure.
author: Brian J.

description: I love the concept of a "do it yourself" sushi wrap.  It is quick and easy for someone who is on the go.  I ordered it with Spicy Salmon, Kamikani, spicy tobiko, cucumber, edamame, onion and with chili mayo sauce.  The roll was tasty and super fresh.  Also, I tried the miso soup, it was really good as well.  One wrap is equivalent to the size of one sushi roll.  I usually eat about 2 rolls of sushi to get full, wish that is was more filling.  If they can make the sushi wrap as big as a mission style burrito, then I will give it a 5 star.
author: Eva E.

description: I tried the fire bowl for the first time today and I am a little torn.  I like the spiciness, different texture with big cubes of salmon, minced spicy tuna, seaweed salad, small pieces of lettuce and small crunchy rice crackers?  It's a good combination and the fish taste pretty fresh.  The biggest disappointment is the rice!  I am usually not picky about my rice but the rice is cooked too mushy here, too much water and it totally ruins the whole experience.  It's an easy fix and I hope they will do something about that because rice is also an important ingredient here.
author: winnie l.

description: Delicious poke rice bowls!  Fresh sushi for a great price!
author: Cy C.

description:
I feel uneasy being the first to "ding" Sushi Taka. People clearly love the place. In fairness, I'm fussy about fish. I don't deal well with challenges. Sushi needs to be fresh and tender. If I have to work to chew on a piece of fish, I spit it out (same goes with finding bones in my fish). If the sinew of a piece of fish tries to lodge itself between my teeth, I spit it out. 

Alas, my spicy salmon roll at Sushi Taka failed to please. The salmon tasted plenty fresh. But I couldn't chew threw the pieces of fish. Believe me, I tried. After gulping down a couple of very stringy, sinewy pieces, I gave up. My appetite was gone. Queasy from the experience, I sipped my tasty bowl of miso and called it a day. Mind you, the rest of the roll ingredients were terrific (love the green tea rice). But the fish - the point of the roll - grossed me out. 

Will I try again? Yes. Service is friendly and efficient. The prices are right and the menu is easy to navigate. Given all the great reviews (until now), I believe the place deserves one more shot. I'll update my review then, but I want to warn those of you who, like me, need their raw fish to submit easily to each bite. Avoid the salmon at Sushi Taka!
author: Steve J.

description:
Not really a sushi, not really a burrito, but definitely not as expensive as Sushiritto. 

It's a bigger sized sushi that they only cut in half instead of into 6 pieces. So forget about using your chopsticks and daintily dipping it in soy sauce, just use your hands to hold roll and munch away. You can choose between a set menu or pick your own toppings, comes up to about $8 after tax. I got the salmon, again, not the freshest, but not the fishiest either. 

Also, there is no seating inside. My friend and I braved the Portsmouth Square Park/Playground and the stares from the old chinese men. At one point, an old man sitting across from us was clipping his toe nails. 

So my advice to you is: get it to go and take it back to your office.
author: Nancie T.

description: Great service, flavors, and prices! I'm a big fan of the miso soup and seaweed salad. My go to work lunch spot.
author: Briana B.

description:
Tasty [and healthy- but don't let that scare you], fresh and customizable take-out sushi rolls!!! This place is perfect for the work lunch run, or for the tourist who doesn't want to sit at the sushi boat resto or get something different from the run of the mill Chinese places in Chinatown...

I've gone with the special of the day the last 3 times I've been here since it opened in early Feb 2012, and each time it's been tasty and filling. Not sure what other reviewers are saying about more food for the money.

The only thing I would want is perhaps for added sides or appys... They are great at what they do- the custom rolls and letting you add extras for their miso soup, but having a little more selection might be great for getting that overall well-rounded meal.

Otherwise, I'd like to share that I liked the Surf N Turf special which was stuffed with beef sukiyaki meat and shrimp tempura, as well as a little spicy sweet radish kimchi.

Right now, cash only!
author: Voon W.

description: Came here to see if this place was better than sushirrito. I got the Sushi Taka Roll. The roll came out in less than a minute. I enjoyed the roll but thought it was alot smaller than the ones offered at Sushirrito. If you check in on yelp, you get a free miso soup. My girlfriend ordered the spicy taka roll which was ok. I actually felt it was weird that there was kim chi in the roll to make it spicy. The service was quick for a small bite but I was still hungry.
author: Jason L.

description:
I dont know where these "great fish" reviews are coming from.

The "hand roll" is wrapped like a burrito (wth?) and the seaweed was CHEWY.  The fish was fresh? I dont know, i coudnt tell since the sauce covered it all up.  The rice was soggy and it overall tasted very nasty.  I got the wasabi sauce which was not "wasabi"-ish at all, i couldnt tell it had any.  I'm glad it was free (part of some promotion with LevelUp app).

No thanks.
author: Jerry J.

description:
DIY Sushi

Green tea rice + choice of main fish + choice of veggies + sauce = a weird roll (in my case). This place is fun and you get to experiment with combining different ingredients a sushi chef normally wouldn't combine. 

FYI, crab mix & tomatoes do not go well together.
author: Jeff L.

description:
I had a sushi roll craving and decided to come here.  I'd say it was worth it.

I got the Queen Roll - spicy salmon, takuan, spicy roe, with spicy mayo.  The size of the roll was a little on the small side but that could just be that my expectation was more of a burritos size. my fault.  The taste was good for a quick lunch.

But anyway, the service was very quick and the man at the register was very friendly.  My friend ordered a miso soup and a 49er roll but realized she didn't want takuan in it and he easily made a substitution for her.  We were in and out of there in 5 minutes.  

There isn't seating so go eat on Bush Street or something.  I'd come here again.  Maybe get 2 rolls.
author: S T.

description: My friend told me that this place was better than Sushiritto so I was like okay lemme try. 4 stars average rating okay that must mean its good. It's on the corner of Kearny and that street where the 1 bus runs going towards Van Ness. I had to pee SO bad at that time and when I went in I asked if they had a restroom but they didn't. There were like 10 workers in the small ass "restaurant". It's not really a restaurant. More like a food court mall booth. You definitely can't dine in. There were hella workers for a small ass place. We got the unagi roll and the salmon roll. The cashier asked if I wanted a bento box or all theses misc stuff they have on the side. I asked if the two rolls will fill us up and he said probably not so I said okay lemme order a spam musubi. I was checking in on Yelp at that time so I got a check in special and got a free miso soup. I checked in with my hubby's phone too so he got one too. We left and ate our food at the park down the street cuz there were benches to sit. The rolls were pretty good but kinda small. They were about $10 each. I forgot if it was $7.99 or $8.99. Anyhoo, my hubby didn't like the miso soup much. After I ate my roll, I looked in my bag and my spam musubi was NOWHERE to be found!!! Grrr!!! I was pissed. They forgot my musubi and I paid for it!! So I walked my ass all the way back and they were closed... Luckily the door wasn't closed. They had blocked the entrance with a bucket or something. I told the guy who seems to be the owner that they had forgot my musubi and he gave me two from the shelf... I was like it's okay??? Cuz I thought those were just displays like synthetic food. He apologized, I took the musubis assuming it was fresh since he's giving it to me and wouldn't give me old ones right??? Went back to the park.... Okay the musubis were old. Tried to eat at least half to get my moneys worth but was simply disappointed instead. So overall....I liked the rolls. The rolls were good. Kinda small. Kinda pricy so I would probably only come here once in a while. I don't recommend getting the musubi because it wasn't good. L&L tastes WAY better. I didn't get the musubi fresh so who knows. Maybe it tastes better fresh? They gave me an old one. The bento box and other random stuff behind the glass displays didn't look good anyways. I didn't get a receipt when I paid AND didn't get a food I ordered so it SEEMED like they were trying to rip me off but I'm sure that's not the case. I would have liked it if they gave me a receipt so I can keep track of my order cuz what if someone makes a big order and they were missing stuff like how I was? The guy who seemed like he was owner was nice. He told me where I could find a public restroom down the street. Nice guy overall. But back to the food...I had a bittersweet experience because they forgot my food and I had to come all the way back and didn't get a fresh one. I would have been happier if they gave me a fresh one. Would I come back? Maybe once in a while. Still kinda small and pricey in my opinion.....so just 3 stars. I was relieved they didn't lock the doors and left when they closed for their lunch break cuz I would have been SO pissed. Maybe they have hella workers cuz during lunch hours hella people come here and they don't want to hold up the line. Yeah it was just weird seeing HELLA people in the small ass store lol.
author: Jan E.

description: walking down financial district trying to get some food for lunch everything around that area is pretty busy at that time but saw this little place that looks good and serve fast i had the roll with crab and tuna and my friend got a chicken teriyaki bowl both where tasty, easy to eat, fulfilling and very affordable gonna come back when around the area since I'm usually not around there. also staff was super helpful, nice and welcoming :))) got to love when you find a lil busyness like this in SF FD!
author: Carolina E.

description: The concept is great, but it cost way to much for what it really was. It was advertised to me by a friend as something more like a sushi burrito. This was just uncut sushi rolls, but the over all quality was very fresh and very tasty.
author: Michael M.

description: For a downtown lunch spot I give it a 4.  My expectations were low b/c I'm picky abt my sushi... I wouldn't go here to get a plate of sashimi, no way, but all wrapped up it works surprisingly well on a lunch level.  The proportions were pretty good, albeit a bit heavy on the rice, the fish was ok, and the combo of spicy salmon, kimchi and guacamole was oddly delicious.  The guac freaked me out in theory (why not fresh avo?) but it totally brought the burrito together in execution.  It's satisfying to the tastebuds and the belly (I was full).  Plus the folks who work here are sweet as pie and I'm a sucker for kindness.
author: Sophie D.

description: MM. Their Musubi smells incredible. I enjoyed my tasty spicy fried chicken and veggie roll with unagi sauce. Just the right amount of decadent. These rolls aren't huge but they are enough food. The staff are super nice. I hope they do well!
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Skip Sushiritto and come to here. The options are better and in my opinion more fresh! You get just as much food only the rolls aren't 70% rice. Also, every time I come here the guys behind the counter are insanely nice.
author: Colie P.

description: I will have to agree with fellow yelper- Sani S., my teriyaki chicken bento box was microwaved and with some sauce thrown in. Everything just seemed way too salty including the miso soup that it came with. Although the young guy at the counter who took my order was super nice, I could not over look all the salt that was in my food.
author: Zannie S.

description: Delicious! I love this place, I go every week, the owner is so nice, he greets you by your name when you become a regular. Perfect lunch size meals.
author: Delia L. A.

description: Great lunch option.  Recommend the sushi rolls over the bento boxes @ lunch (they seem to be better at sushi).
author: Erik J.

description: I go here often as it is right next to my office building - stuff is always fresh and yummy and so different which is nice 'cause I eat sushi at least three times a week. Today I had something (for the first time) that wasnt quite right. When I brought it to their attention they were SO nice about it. This is the sign of a business I like supporting when they always make it right!
author: Darcey R.

description:
My sister and I tried this place for the first time the other day, which coincidentally was their 6-month anniversary. Yay for 35% off and good timing!

Ordered:
1 King Roll and 1 Warriors Roll

The King Roll was delicious! I love spicy food and if you do too, this is the menu item to order. Even if you don't like spicy food, this roll is pretty mild, so don't be afraid to give it a try. This roll consisted of green tea flavored rice (standard rice in all their rolls), spicy salmon, kimchi, spicy kanikama (crab meat), and soy mayo. 

The Warriors/Worriers Roll (different spelling on their actual store menu and their online menu) consisted of tuna, guacamole, kanikama, and soy mayo. This roll felt more burrioto-esque with the guacamole. The flavors were okay but it was missing the wow factor. Perhaps, changing the sauce may help? I would not order this again. 

Both rolls were not too overwhelmingly large and they had decent amounts of each ingredient. The rice to ingredients ratio was perfect. 

This place is small, so do not expect a sit down and relaxed atmosphere. Although they  do have two foldable chairs for patrons to sit, the space is very tight, almost claustrophobic small. 

Great customer service and very friendly staff. 

The overall consensus is that the King Roll is the roll to order if you're trying this place for the first time. I will definitely frequent this place to try the other menu items and once I figure out which items I like the best, I'll customize my rolls.
author: Kit K.

description: not my cup of tea.  its about over blown rolls with tons of stuff in them, and you get to pick what goes in.  if you want sushi nigiri, don't come here!  (that's what I wanted!)  the fish isn't not fresh, but it's also not prime.  and there isn't a lot of it in the rolls; but there is a lot of egg and mayonnaise and guacamole and, well, extraneous STUFF.  i'm sure some people like it, but not me.  yuck.  and it's all to go.  just so you know.
author: gary g.

description: I popped in here on a lunchtime adventure in the FiDi, and was wary of the burrito-size sushi rolls...but 5 min later while I was happily chowing down on them in a secluded rooftop park, I was very pleased! They added some random stuff to my roll that wasn't on the menu with a smile, it tasted superb, and it wasn't terribly expensive. I WILL be hitting this place up again.
author: Rylan S.

description: I went here awhile back, and now i am getting a chance to review. Really great staff, the owner is a really nice gentleman. Took the time to explain what combinations were good, since i am not sure and what all the sushi things are. Oh man but what a concept a sushi burrito thats how i can best describe it. Everything is fresh, and great flavors. This isnt too close to my work but when me and my coworker are in a need for alittle walk i always recommend to go here. I cant wait to go here again.
author: Jan V.

description: very good.  Fresh.  Better than Sushiritto?  I think so!
author: Jordan S.

description: Just went here for the first time today with my gf. I have to say, I walked away satisfied and impressed. The staff was extremely friendly and serviceable. They were happy to explain the way things work (you can build your own sushi burrito) for first timers like us. Our food was prepared extremely quickly (that being said we were the only ones there, 11:15 lunch FTW) and we were out the door within 5-10 minutes of walking in. The sushi burrito itself was a little weird at first but quite delicious! I remember saying that I wanted another as soon as I finished. The only downside I can think of is that one burrito sometimes is not filling enough. And for $8 I usually like to be a little more full after a meal. Other than that though I would absolutely recommend this place and I have every intention of going back to try more!
author: Cooper J.

description: I happened to be randomly on this street when the guy standing outside the restaurant caught my attention. Next to him on a display table was a large sushi roll, similar to a burrito (sushirito?) and the grand opening announcement, (I'm always one to support lil mom and pops). Got the Chef's Special which included a sushi roll and a drink for $9 dollars (damn Gina).  In a hurry,  and on my way out, the owners literally shook my hand to thank me for my biz. Running off to my meeting, 3 hours later, (at 5:30pm), I *finally* ate my "lunch." Expecting the sushirito to be gross and soggy, ingredients inside were STILL fresh and crisp- and the flavor...MAN,  So flavorful and SO GOOD- I wanted MOOOORE. I could eat one of these everyday. Can't wait to go back. Only complaint: portions not big enough for the price.
author: Rebecca S.

description: How this place has 4 stars is beyond me. The only reason I deemed this "restaurant" worthy of 2 stars was due to the friendly staff; however, no amount of charm can compensate for the atrocious food. My coworker and I each ordered two rolls and were decently excited to try the food after reading the positive reviews. After one bite of each we immediately threw the rolls in the trash and opted to eat the stale cereal sitting around at the office. Sushiritto blows this place out of the water and it's not even that good. Do yourself a favor and go to Tokyo Express.
author: Stephan S.

description: First time here today for lunch to go.  Got the California roll and miso soup.  it was very good, tasted good and the Krab tasted fresh.  the larger size roll - the taste texture is more firm like if you were eating spam musubi.  i like that.  the miso soup was good and hot.  other people have already commented about the price, i used a groupon.  In short, the Roll was good and i could eat a whole bucket of that Krab.  i'll try spicy next time.  Also the guys were very polite.
author: hugh L.

description: Sorry, this place was not at all worth coming to.  Rolls were just weird.  If 7-11 was to do sushi, this is what it would be like.
author: Nobody M.

description: The rolls are good. Sadly, I can't help but feel as though I'm always getting skimped on the fish.. Who knows, maybe I'm a crazy person.
author: Tom B.

description: What a great invention. This is the best sushi roll I ever had in this format. It's like a burrito from the sea food heavens!  I got the seaweed salad to back it up- a perfect mix of vinegar and kelp! I'll go back every week!
author: Mark L.

description:
This place is great.  I've eaten here about 4 times now since they opened just a few months back.  The sushi is always fresh and the price and amount is just right. 

They don't necessarily have the variety of Ebisu a few blocks down but for me the location is much more convenient, the guys who own/work there are much more personal, and the price is way more reasonable for what you get.  The "do it yourself" concept is kind of coook but it's great that they have the more standard pre-set rolls.

Highly recommend with or without the Yelp deal.
author: C A.

description: similar to Sushirrito, but not as big.  Customizability is a big plus, but for the $10-12 price you don't really get your money's worth.
author: Arvindh K.

description: DIY sushi roll who would've thought? Someone new and out of the ordinary. The tea flavored rice and fresh ingredients def makes this place a lot better than sushiritto. Not to mention the owner is super awesome!!!!
author: sengmany m.

description: Friendly and delicious, but they're a bit slow with their service sometimes. The rolls are mainly rice so I recommend getting a bowl. It's a lot more filling and worth your money!
author: Tiffamy C.

description: The yelp coupon is certainly a big motivator for me to walk over and try this new place. I was hoping to find a replacement to the fantastic Good Luck deli and the Vietnamese Sandwich place and this seems to fit the bill. The sushi wrap is not huge, which is perfect for someone is weight consious. I didn't try the salmon due to the reviews I'm reading here, but the Miso California Roll was a right choice, a bit salty but flavor is quiet good. The rice is really good, not sure how exactly they made it, but very fresh, moist but not sticky. So important for a rice roll. I also got the green tea cake, given I still have room to consume.
author: Daveen L.

description: Friendly, clean, simple, amazingly fresh tuna, salmon, and veggies.  For $8 you get a roll the size of an overstuffed burrito.  The sauces compare to a $15+ specialty roll at upscale joints.  If you find yourself working in Nob Hill for a few days, do yourself a favor and cruise on down to Chinatown (via California Ave) for lunch.  If you work at one of the financial institutions on the corner of Cali and Kearney, you probably already know what a gem Sushi Taka is!
author: Michael M.

description: This is a little far from where I work, so I've only been once. The sushi is probably one of the best I've ever tasted. The staff is very friendly and respectful. I've no complaints.
author: Clar S.

description: I ordered a bento box, which according to a photo right below the cash register was supposed to have beef. What I got was some rice with a hint of fatty chewy beef. I am not kidding! It was one bite of fatty chewy beef! I asked the owner if that is all the beef he will put on there. His response, in the polite Japanese manner was that he will start putting more been in the dish next time. Sushi that was included was essentially a ball of rice with a super thin slide of fish on top. What's worse is they charged me $10+ for that mess. Awful!
author: Andre K.

description: Owner is really nice, rolls are yummy, good price. I would suggest they add some premade rolls to their menu for ppl who wanna pick up something quick, though they are super quick already. Def recommend!
author: Ting Z.

description: So friendly and delicious!!!! I like it better than sushirrito also :)
author: Brynn B.

description: Tried the "Chef's special" roll--delicious. My only issue is that I was hungry again soon after, i.e. it's not very filling.
author: Maximillian M.

description: After passing by this place a couple times , I finally decided to try it the other day . You can choose your own fish , toppings , veggies , and sauce for your own sushi roll but their toppings and veggies are kinda weird ... they're not things that you would normally put or want to put in your sushi rolls . I decided to stick with a spicy salmon roll with tobiko, cucumber , and spicy mayo which was actually not bad ( suprisingly ) . The roll ended up looking like a burrito / wrap cut in half . In addition to the roll , I also had their miso soup which was not bad . It's kind of cool how they use a miso soup dispenser machine and how they let you add your own toppings . I would like this place more if they offered avocado as a topping ...
author: Eileen L.

description: It was pretty good -more like 3.5. as everyone else has said, nic is really nice. i guess my main grievance is that it's small - the roll is pretty small and the seaweed salad was TINY for $2.50. seemed like a good deal with the yelp deal, but maybe less so at full price. i also made a giant mess eating it, but that's maybe my fault because i was trying to dip it in soy sauce like normal roll pieces. pro tip: put the soy sauce on it, not the other way around, lest all the filling comes out.
author: Erica W.

description: This is a unique sushi type place, because they serve "build your own" rolls...sort of like Chipotle does with burritos.  Very high quality, tasty ingredients make for a great sushi roll at a great price.  Give it a try!!
author: Briar S.

description: Terrific fresh lunch options, super-friendly place.  Rolls you can carry away and eat on the go.
author: E. E.

description: If you've been to usushi on Market, Sushi Taka is a close replicate. Same concept - pick a main item (fish/beef/tofu), veggies, sauce and it all gets rolled up like a burrito.  They also have standard rolls like spicy tuna, california, etc in addition to the DIY rolls.  Their rolls are definitely bigger than usushi's and about the size of the ones from Sushirrito.  Majority of the rolls are $7.50 plus tax.  I tried the spicy tuna - ingredients are fresh and flavorful, easily hits the spot.  They only slice the roll in half, so you'll basically have to eat it like a burrito.  The only frustrating part is getting soy sauce and wasabi on the roll; you gotta methodically bite the thing so that it's easier to dip.  If only there was such a thing as sushi salsa.  Somebody get on that!  Also this isn't a restaurant, just an indoor food stand.  Overall, a nice and healthy option for lunch and a good spot to swing by for a quick sushi fix.  Cash only!
author: Jeff S.

description: This type of DIY sushi roll shops are popping up everywhere.   First, with Sushiritto...then i-sushi. Sushiritto's roll is the biggest.  They all taste the same, since I'm not expecting the high quality sashimi in these rolls.   What makes this place stand out is even though the location and shop is not as fancy, the service is great!  I felt really welcomed by the owner when I came in. :)  I'll come again.
author: K W.

description: Finally... a nearby sushi takeout place that doesn't come off as the next McDonald's of sushi.  The roll I got was fantastic, and the owner was super friendly and helpful.  This will get a place in my standard lunch rotation for sure.
author: David I.

description: Very creative sushi, like curry california roll.  I only eat authentic sushi and I don't think there combination will work.  I am wrong, can't imagine the green tea mix with rice taste so good, Spicy tuna and salmon in their creation work like magic.  It may be a fast food place, but you can experience beyond other Japanese restaurant.
author: Tim W.

description: Checked this place out today with my fiancee (we used the Yelp coupon). I had the Duke Roll and he had the 49ers roll. I was happy with my roll in regards to size, flavor, and, if I were to go back, the menu price but my fiancee's roll was a bit smaller than mine which we thought was odd. I would think all the rolls should come out to about the same size since most of the burrito is filler anyway. His roll cost a little more because it had tuna in it so that was reasonable enough but it shouldn't mean his roll should be smaller. The roll was still tasty though. We also each ordered a cup of miso soup which was also flavorful but in our opinion a bit pricey had we not had the coupon. It's $2 for a small cup. I think somewhere under $2 is more reasonable. Service was friendly (met Nick the owner) and fast. I'd consider going back again for lunch.
author: D T.

description: The folks at Sushi Taka make decent-tasting and healthy fast food. Ingredients are fresh and sized appropriately. The only thing tricky about this place was, it doesn't really tell you that you're ordering a burrito-looking sushi roll until you've come 2 feet away from the place. Perhaps this confusion is the reason why it's almost always empty everytime I pass by.
author: benita b.
